title: 24-808_k53l
question_text: So you're not arguing that your motion, your 60(b) motion, was filed within a reasonable amount of time?
answer_text: We believe, Your Honor, that there is no reasonable amount of time within which a judgment that is void ab initio can be vacated.

title: 24-808_k53l
question_text: How is void ab initio different from the grounds listed in 60(b), the judgment is void, as a basis for the motion? Heritage Reporting Corporation
answer_text: Subject to Final Review

title: 24-808_k53l
question_text: So how do you respond to Respondent's argument that you're conflating the merits with the timeliness of the motion?
answer_text: Well, we believe, Your Honor, that if a judgment is void ab initio, there -- there is no timeliness aspect that would cause -- that should cause a court to not vacate that judgment.

title: 24-808_k53l
question_text: Suppose a -- a district court issues a judgment that is void ab initio and the party against which the judgment is entered waits a year before filing a notice of appeal. Would the court of appeals be obligated to entertain that appeal?
answer_text: I think it would, Your Heritage Reporting Corporation

title: 24-808_k53l
question_text: I mean, that does seem to be the logic of the idea of a judgment being void ab initio, and we addressed that last term in Hewitt versus the United States, not a case that -- it's a criminal case, but still, we talked about void ab initio and we said, if a judgment is void ab initio, it never -- it's as if it never existed. It was erased from the historical record. So the -- what you're saying does follow from the logic of that, but doesn't it seem strange that the appellant would have an unlimited amount of time to appeal from a judgment that's void ab initio?
answer_text: I think even a void judgment can be -- can be given effect if the defendant or the judgment debtor acquiesces to the court's jurisdiction. And so, if, for Heritage Reporting Corporation

title: 24-808_k53l
question_text: What about fraudulent judgments? Is -- do you think that they can be challenged at -- at any time as well, or there's no ground on which they can be reopened?
answer_text: Well, I believe fraudulent judgments are covered by Rule 60(b)(3), which requires a -- which requires a -- or which must be filed within one year. And so that timeliness aspect applies through Rule 60(c)(1), as well as Rule 60(b)(3).

title: 24-808_k53l
question_text: Don't we have procedural rules that sort of just limit your ability to make that claim and really don't speak to the issue of whether or not it's actually void; you just have to make that allegation within a particular period of time?
answer_text: Justice Jackson, I would say that void judgments or judgments void ab initio are within a separate class, and so the Constitution requires that void judgments not be given effect.

title: 24-808_k53l
question_text: Right. But what if we don't know whether or not this is a void judgment? I mean, that's the issue, right?
answer_text: That's -- that's the -- the merits claim that Heritage Reporting Corporation

title: 24-808_k53l
question_text: Doesn't the court have to decide whether or not it's a void judgment in order to determine whether or not you have filed this in a time -- in a timely fashion?
answer_text: Well, the -- yes. Obviously, you have to make a motion.

title: 24-808_k53l
question_text: Subject to Final Review you did, in fact, proceed in a reasonable time. Is that correct?
answer_text: Yes, Your Honor. We believe that, again, if a judgment is void ab initio, then the reasonable time does

title: 24-808_k53l
question_text: -- the alternative argument is not before us that you -- you complied with (c)(1), right?
answer_text: That's correct, Your Honor.

title: 24-808_k53l
question_text: -- would -- would would your client be able to file a (d) motion, a collateral attack to the judgment?
answer_text: Justice Gorsuch, the

title: 24-808_k53l
question_text: Do you really want to give up the (d)(1) argument?
answer_text: I guess it would depend on -- on -- on exactly what the Court's holding is. So, if

title: 24-808_k53l
question_text: How would you have us write it to preserve that option for you? (Laughter.)
answer_text: I guess I would -- I would request

title: 24-808_k53l
question_text: If you had this independent collateral action, whether under 60(d)(1) or imagine a world without 60(b) and you can just bring an independent collateral attack on the judgment, would the defense of laches apply, or would your reasoning there be that, no, there just can never be any limitation, no statute of limitation, no laches defense from the other side if a judgment is void ab initio?
answer_text: I would say, Justice Barrett, that, yes, there is no laches argument to be made in connection with a void judgment in -- in -- void in the pure sense of the term.

title: 24-808_k53l
question_text: Subject to Final Review defeat your common law understanding?
answer_text: I believe, Your Honor, that if we were to -- or -- or, if the Court were to rule that -- that laches cannot apply to a void judgment, then that would

title: 24-808_k53l
question_text: -- because you say there's a common law. But, if there isn't a common law because there were laches applied by some courts, not all of them but some, doesn't that defeat your argument?
answer_text: I would say, Your Honor, that -- that it would not defeat the argument because, if the Court were to find that -- that a void judgment cannot be given effect for due process reasons

title: 24-808_k53l
question_text: And so if we look at what the Advisory Committee said when it was creating 60(b) was that it wanted to -- because the existing rules in common law were "confusing," one of the purposes of the amendment was to clarify the rule so that the federal rule will provide -- will be controlling. So what do we do with that?
answer_text: Well, because the void -- the -- the enforcement of a void judgment, even to overcome laches, would require a violation of due process.

title: 24-808_k53l
question_text: Could Congress write a rule that says exactly what you want even void judgments need to be filed within a reasonable time? Does Congress have the power to do that?
answer_text: I was going to say, Your Honor, I don't think Congress has that power because the Constitution -- because of the Due Process Clause. And so, if the Court were to find in Coney Island's

title: 24-808_k53l
question_text: What falls within the category of void judgments in your mind? Like, what's -- what's -- what are the range of things that are in the category?
answer_text: It would have to be and the Court has -- has spoken on this several times. It would have to be a judgment that was entered in the absence of subject matter jurisdiction, personal jurisdiction, or some other defect that would cause a similar effect.

title: 24-808_k53l
question_text: Subject to Final Review category?
answer_text: Potentially, bribery of a judicial official or some other -- some other defect that -- that goes to the very heart of -- of the court's power to hear a dispute.

title: 24-808_k53l
question_text: But your argument would necessarily mean that any time limits as to raising a personal jurisdiction issue would -- would be invalid, is that correct?
answer_text: Yes, Your Honor.

title: 24-808_k53l
question_text: What have the
answer_text: I was just going to say your friend on the -- argues that you're conflating two concepts, whether a void judgment can become valid, I suppose, in some abstract sense and what the procedures are for vacating a judgment. I guess you assume that even if the judgment -- that it must be vacated. On the other hand, I think the argument is that -- I don't know whether it's in an abstract sense, you consider the judgment, even though valid, it can't -- under Heritage Reporting Corporation

title: 24-808_k53l
question_text: Can you think of
answer_text: But the Rules of Civil Procedure, for example, say, you know, that when a suit is brought and you have a personal jurisdiction defense, you have to raise that defense before the answer or, you know, with the answer, if you file an answer. Heritage Reporting Corporation

title: 24-808_k53l
question_text: Subject to Final Review You know, there's some sense of, like, when you're supposed to file your personal jurisdiction defense, and if you don't and if you wait forever, it's lost. Would that also be -- you know, we should basically say that that rule is unconstitutional, a violation of due process?
answer_text: No, Justice Kagan.

title: 24-808_k53l
question_text: What have the courts of appeals and the commentators, Moore's, Wright and Miller, said about this question and whether there's a reasonable time limitation on seeking relief from a judgment that's void ab initio? Heritage Reporting Corporation
answer_text: Subject to Final Review

title: 24-808_k53l
question_text: Thank you, counsel. Anything further? Anything further?
answer_text: No.

title: 24-808_k53l
question_text: Thank you, counsel. Ms. Blatt?
answer_text: ORAL ARGUMENT OF LISA S. BLATT ON BEHALF OF THE RESPONDENT

title: 24-808_k53l
question_text: Is there a way to challenge a void judgment beyond Rule 60?
answer_text: We don't think so based on the text of the rule and the history. The rule itself is pretty expansive. It says it is the way to get relief from a valid judgment.

title: 24-808_k53l
question_text: I want to be clear, Ms. Blatt, in this case, we don't have a question, although the Sixth Circuit acknowledged it, about whether the reasonable time period should only start when enforcement is attempted, correct?
answer_text: Correct. And

title: 24-808_k53l
question_text: -- your -- the Petitioners here raise a Rules Enabling Act argument but only in reply, so you didn't get a chance to address it in the briefs. Do you want to take a moment to focus on that here?
answer_text: Sure. As I understand the Rules Enabling Act, it just can't enlarge rights, but I think that's another version of, well, you're giving effect to a judgment that, by hypothesis, might be void, kind of spring to life. And I think you quite nicely said there's just a procedural bar that you have to go through to get your right to argue that it's -- it's void or get relief from it.

title: 24-808_k53l
question_text: Subject to Final Review and the leading commentators take the opposite position. How do you account for that?
answer_text: So I think that's correct. I think these courts were writing, you know, either now or at the time in a way that they were comfortable not following the literal text. Some of them acknowledge that they're not following the literal text and this is just not consistent with the Court's modern approach.

title: 24-808_k53l
question_text: I mean, doesn't that lead to the conclusion that was drawn by all these courts of appeals?
answer_text: No, and here's why. In addition to it's conflating the grounds for relief in 60(b), you know, fraud by the opposing party, and you've already paid the judgment -- you know, you've already paid it; how can you make me pay it twice? And the example we give in the brief, and I think it's quite instructive, is the area of preclusion.

title: 24-808_k53l
question_text: Well, then what should we say about void ab initio in our opinion? Well, I mean, it doesn't really erase it from the annals of history. It has -- that's an overstatement?
answer_text: It's not an overstatement to -- to describe fraud on -- on the court or fraud by the other party are void ab initio. It's -- that's the grounds when you get into court under Rule 60. That's the procedure where you get relief from that judgment.

title: 24-808_k53l
question_text: Well, if -- suppose the reasonable time limit applies, and I know maybe we don't have to decide what that means here, but if we were to decide that, would you agree that there should be a lot more flexibility with regard to a -- the reasonableness of a filing when what is being contested is a judgment that's void ab initio?
answer_text: No.

title: 24-808_k53l
question_text: You don't think that couldn't -- that wouldn't -- no?
answer_text: I think a default judgment might. Like, I think a default judgment just raises implications, you need to hear of it. But just I -- I think at least the way the rule's set up, maybe how void it is somehow bears on why you took so long.

title: 24-808_k53l
question_text: But do you think there's any category of cases in which a reasonable amount of time can, in fact, be any time?
answer_text: No. I mean, that's infinity. So

title: 24-808_k53l
question_text: -- that -- that whenever you raise it, it will be considered?
answer_text: No. By definition, it's conceiving that there could be an unreasonable time and any time. Now, that being said, you could say, you know, I'm happy to give you any number, a billion years, I'm just not going to concede any because it has to be reasonable.

title: 24-808_k53l
question_text: So your concept of reasonable time, it seems to me, carries with it some idea or consideration of the prejudice to the other side. Is that right?
answer_text: Well, prejudice to the judgment creditor and I just think you could reasonably take into account the burden on what Justice Sotomayor was saying about, you know, did the person lack resources. I think Heritage Reporting Corporation

title: 24-808_k53l
question_text: - wouldn't it be reasonable for that person to have more time to seek relief from this -- from this judgment?
answer_text: Yes. So I was trying to concede a lot with Justice Sotomayor, but I don't think Rule 60 applies to state judgments. I think you've got to go to the
